Message.Msg: Notice that Exxon was the weakest oil stock today and one of the weakest Dow stocks. Has badly trailed all averages for the last 4 years. Stock hurt by terrible XTO acquisition. Stock a real underperformer since Rex Tillerson became CEO.

Message.Title: XTO
Message.Msg: At the time of the XTO acquisition CEO Rex Tillerson said over and over that the deal would be beneficial to shareholders despite poor reviews the deal received from analysts. Earlier this year in a speech, he said that Exxon was "losing its shirt on natural gas." How can one have confidence in this man and his management team. Wall Steet certainly doesn't.

Message.Title: Polls show wealthy want higher taxes
Message.Msg: The reason why is very simple: There are very few good investments in the world these days, which is why tens trillions of dollars, tens of trillions of euros, and trillions of pounds are squeezed into bank deposits and bonds earning nothing. Stocks earn nothing either, bid up to such lofty heights, although some dreamers hope they will. The stocks are bid there because corporations do not have investment opportunities for capital and could not put investor funds to work on projects even if they sold stock, making it impossible for the stock market to absorb the capital except with inflation of the stock prices. Worse still corporations are buying back stock with monies they cannot invest, which just compounds the glut of capital and extreme inflation of stock values. The solution is obvious: The government must invest the glut of capital in public goods, and the responsible way to go about financing that is higher taxes. Investments in infrastructure, education, energy research, military weapon systems with their associated spin-off technologies, medicine, genetic engineering, and other areas of public spending, offer far greater return than the near zero returns possible now the capital glutted private sector. Investing in basic education and cultural improvement projects to improve the productivity of minorities in cities and backward elements in rural areas promises good returns too. Nuclear fusion, superconductors, advanced alloys, nanotechnologies, artificial intelligence and military & industrial robotics, cloaking technologies, space transportation, communications, and weapon systems are fields that could soak up capital. Then there is the idiocy of running the budget deficits when such vast income, income that far beyond the spending ability of individuals, is available. For those brainwashed by visions of small businesses earning lottery returns, or riding the next stock to a fortune such views probably seem strange. Such people lack perspective.
If you believe that, you have been drunk for the last 4 years. I should have suspected that all along.

Topic.Title: Wayne Lapierre This Weeks Voice From He!!

Message.Msg: -- Mayan Palace Theater, San Antonio, Texas, this week: Jesus Manuel Garcia shoots at a movie theater, a police car and bystanders from the nearby China Garden restaurant; as he enters the movie theater, guns blazing, an armed off-duty cop shoots Garcia four times, stopping the attack. Total dead: Zero. -- Winnemucca, Nev., 2008: Ernesto Villagomez opens fire in a crowded restaurant; concealed carry permit-holder shoots him dead. Total dead: Two. (I'm excluding the shooters' deaths in these examples.) -- Appalachian School of Law, 2002: Crazed immigrant shoots the dean and a professor, then begins shooting students; as he goes for more ammunition, two armed students point their guns at him, allowing a third to tackle him. Total dead: Three. -- Santee, Calif., 2001: Student begins shooting his classmates -- as well as the "trained campus supervisor"; an off-duty cop who happened to be bringing his daughter to school that day points his gun at the shooter, holding him until more police arrive. Total dead: Two. -- Pearl High School, Mississippi, 1997: After shooting several people at his high school, student heads for the junior high school; assistant principal Joel Myrick retrieves a .45 pistol from his car and points it at the gunman's head, ending the murder spree. Total dead: Two. -- Edinboro, Pa., 1998: A student shoots up a junior high school dance being held at a restaurant; restaurant owner pulls out his shotgun and stops the gunman. Total dead: One. By contrast, the shootings in gun-free zones invariably result in far higher casualty figures -- Sikh temple, Oak Creek, Wis. (six dead); Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va. (32 dead); Columbine High School, Columbine, Colo. (12 dead); Amish school, Lancaster County, Pa. (five little girls killed); public school, Craighead County, Ark. (five killed, including four little girls). All these took place in gun-free zones, resulting in lots of people getting killed -- and thereby warranting inclusion in the Mother Jones study. If what we care about is saving the lives of innocent human beings by reducing the number of mass public shootings and the deaths they cause, only one policy has ever been shown to work: concealed-carry laws. On the other hand, if what we care about is self-indulgent grandstanding, and to hell with dozens of innocent children being murdered in cold blood, try the other policies.
greed u r a sick twisted #$%$ dik.
